page.title: 02Inversnaid landscape
page.content: We are in a valley between Stob-an-Fhainne (2144ft) and Cruachan (1762ft). This is a{"hanging valley".} The Arklet Water runs through this valley from the dam at Loch Arklet to the falls at Loch Lomond. The valley is called{Glen Arklet.}The Snaid burn runs from North to South beside the school,where it meets the Arklet there is an old wooden bridge. The land is hilly. There is bracken,heather and bog myrtle with rough grazing for the sheep. On the lower slopes,birch, willow and rowan grow with oak, birch,hazel and alder along Loch Lomondside. Rhododendron grows wild. Beyond the railway in Kenmore Wood (W. Loch Lomond) there is a spruce plantation.{Milky Quartz}rocks are most common. A small mass of{diorite } occurs at Inversnaid.
